TITOLO: Saggar pottery vase with smoky grey textures and copper marks
DESCRIZIONE: Small stoneware vessel thrown on the potter's wheel and finished through an organic saggar firing. The clouded grey surfaces and deep black lines resulted from carbon vapors and smoke trapped during the process. Soft orange highlights appeared where copper salts reacted with the clay body inside the saggar chamber. Natural markings from burnt leaves and sawdust were captured directly on the surface, making the fire's movement visible. The vase was hand-polished with mineral wax to shield the clay and enhance its earthy matte texture. A quiet decorative element that sits well as a simple accent or a holder for dried stems. This piece is for decorative use and is not water-tight.

TITOLO: Grey saggar fired vase with copper salt markings and carbon trails
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase shaped on the potter's wheel and decorated through a saggar firing process.
The grey tones and dark lines were created by carbon vapors and smoke from natural materials like leaves and sawdust. Bright light orange hues emerged from the reaction of copper salts during the transformation inside the saggar. The surface features sharp black traces that record the unpredictable movement of the fire.
The piece was treated with mineral wax to protect the clay and maintain its natural matte appearance. A quiet decorative element that works as a simple accent or a holder for dried stems.

TITOLO: Cream white rounded saggar fired vase with green copper traces and smoke marks
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase featuring a natural cream white surface with organic markings. The clay displays subtle green traces left by copper and delicate grey smoke effects from the firing process and black copper wire. Every mark is a permanent record of the minerals and organic materials reacting inside the saggar.
The piece is finished with mineral wax to protect the surface and preserve its soft matte texture. This piece sits well as a simple decorative accent or a holder for dried flowers in rustic and minimalist spaces. As the saggar firing process leaves the stoneware naturally porous this vessel is for decorative purposes and dried flowers only as it is not water-tight.

TITOLO: Orange saggar fired vase with copper wire lines, carbon trails and iron oxide
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase created using the saggar firing technique to capture natural mineral marks.
The warm orange surface features sharp black lines left by copper wire and soft, clouded carbon trails. Red iron oxide patches and grey shades from burnt leaves and sawdust add depth to the clay surface. Every mark is a permanent record of the fire and the materials used making this a one-of-a-kind tactile object.
The piece is finished with mineral wax to protect the surface and enhance its natural earthy tones.

This piece sits well as a simple decorative accent or a holder for dried flowers in rustic and minimalist spaces.
As the saggar firing process leaves the stoneware naturally porous this vessel is for decorative purposes and dried flowers only as it is not water-tight.

TITOLO: Antiqued Raku vase with blue-purple reflections inside and cold smoke markings outside
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase shaped on the potter's wheel and finished through two separate decoration stages. The first phase involved a Raku reduction firing to develop blue and purple reflections on the interior. Once cooled, the piece underwent a second process where cold smoke from sawdust and dried grass created organic markings on the exterior. Iron oxide spots and traces of burnt organic matter were captured directly on the clay, recording the unpredictable nature of the fire.
This double firing technique created a unique dialogue between the glazed surfaces and the raw, smoky texture of the outside. The vase was treated with mineral wax to protect the surface and keep its natural appearance over time. This piece sits well as a simple decorative accent or a holder for dried flowers, perfect for rustic and minimalist spaces.
As the Raku process left the stoneware naturally porous this vessel is for decorative purposes and dried flowers only as it is not water-tight.

TITOLO: Small saggar fired ceramic vase with smoke effects and organic plant impressions
DESCRIZIONE:
Small handmade stoneware vase made with the saggar firing technique.
The grey and charcoal shades are natural smoke effects captured on the clay during the firing process.
Direct imprints from plant materials leave delicate traces on the surface making this piece a collaboration with nature.
Each mark is a unique record of the organic matter consumed by the fire creating a tactile object with a simple wabi-sabi aesthetic.
This piece works well as a desk accent or a decorative bud vase for small dried flowers bringing a touch of botanical art into minimalist interiors.
The smoke patterns and plant traces are entirely unique and impossible to repeat making this a one-of-a-kind vessel.
As the saggar firing process leaves the stoneware naturally porous this vessel is for decorative purposes and dried flowers only as it is not water-tight.

TITOLO: Wabi Sabi Raku ceramic vase with organic crackle textures for minimalist interiors
DESCRIZIONE:
Handmade Raku vase featuring an organic crackle texture that echoes parched earth and natural formations. The contrast od colors is created through the traditional Raku process where the deep velvety black finish is pure carbon smoke captured during the firing.
Crafted from high-quality stoneware this piece is a tactile exploration of fire and earth perfect for minimalist or Zen-inspired interiors. The vase is intended for decorative purposes and dried flowers only as Raku is naturally porous and not guaranteed to be water-tight.

TITOLO: Decorative saggar little vase
DESCRIZIONE: This wheel-thrown vase features a vibrant range of reds and oranges, accented by smoky marks and delicate leaf imprints. Burnished with a smooth stone to achieve a natural sheen, the unglazed surface reflects ancient ceramic traditions. Each pattern is one of a kind, created through a spontaneous saggar firing where organic materials, salts, and copper wire react to produce unique textures and tones. Finished with a natural protective wax, this small decorative object is perfect for dried plants or as a standalone piece of art.

TITOLO: Handmade raku stoneware yellow vase – wabi-sabi decorative for dining room, entryway & fireplace. Warm charm unique piece of ceramic.
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase designed as a decorative home accent.
The piece was wheel-thrown and fired using the American raku technique, featuring a handmade glaze in warm old-yellow tones with copper glaze brushstrokes.

The unglazed areas turned black due to the smoke produced during raku firing, permanently fixed into the clay body.

This small vase is perfect as a decorative object for a dining room, entryway, or fireplace, adding a touch of wabi-sabi aesthetics and artisanal character. Ideal for enhancing warm and welcoming atmospheres.

TITOLO: Small aqua blue raku ceramic vase for dried flowers or home decor
DESCRIZIONE:
Small stoneware vase designed as a decorative home accent.
The piece was wheel-thrown and fired using the American raku technique, with a handmade glaze in aqua blue tones, enhanced by yellow brushstrokes.

In American raku, the ceramic piece is removed from the kiln while still glowing hot and placed into closed containers with combustible materials. This process gives the glazes unique and unrepeatable colors and surface effects.
The unglazed areas, still porous at high temperatures, absorb the smoke during the reduction process, which becomes permanently fixed in the clay body. The black areas are a natural result of this process.

TITOLO: White raku ceramic candle holder tray, craquelé effect, black moon, warm home atmosphere
DESCRIZIONE:
Raku Stoneware Candle Holder – Starry Sky and Moon
This candle holder represents a starry sky: the candlelight shines through the stars, creating a warm and cozy glow in your room. At the top, a small crescent moon is depicted.

The dome-shaped candle holder is integrated with a tray, made as a single piece: the dome and tray are not separate elements. The piece was wheel-thrown, while the holes and the moon were entirely handcrafted.

The white glaze is handmade, producing a striking black craquelé effect typical of raku. Being American raku, the piece was removed from the kiln while still glowing hot and placed in a closed container with combustible materials. This allows smoke to penetrate the unglazed areas, giving the moon and the glaze cracks their unique black color.

As visible in the photos, the tray features a small white trapezoid. This is a fragment of a pyrometric cone, an object used to measure heat work in ceramic kilns, which fused with the piece during firing. Rather than a flaw, it is a trace of how unexpected elements can become distinctive features in handmade ceramics, especially in the raku technique, enhancing the material and artisanal character.

This unique handmade piece is perfect for creating warm and one-of-a-kind atmospheres in your home.

TITOLO: Aqua blue raku vase for decorative home use
DESCRIZIONE:
Stoneware vase designed as a decorative home accent.
The piece was wheel-thrown and fired using the American raku technique, with a handmade glaze in aqua blue tones.

In American raku, the ceramic piece is removed from the kiln while still glowing hot and placed into closed containers with combustible materials. This process gives the glazes unique and unrepeatable colors and surface effects.

TITOLO: Decorative white horsehair raku vase, black feather marks, gold kintsugi, inspired by traditional Japanese chawans
DESCRIZIONE:
Decorative white stoneware vase, ideal as a tabletop accent. Inspired by the shape of chawan, the traditional Japanese tea ceremony cups.

The vase was treated with white terra sigillata and polished, then decorated using the horsehair raku technique, which left black smoke marks from feathers on the hot surface. Cracks formed from thermal shocks were intentionally highlighted and repaired with modern gold kintsugi, creating a unique and refined effect.

Finally, the vase was treated and polished with natural wax to protect the surface and preserve its beauty over time.

Although inspired by traditional Japanese tea cups, this piece is purely decorative and not suitable for food use.

TITOLO: Saggar white vase with black, orange, and light gray marks – unglazed, for dried flowers
DESCRIZIONE:
This stoneware vase is designed as a decorative piece, also perfect for dried flowers.

Wheel-thrown, the vase was treated with a white sealed clay and polished to enhance the natural luster of the terracotta. Each pattern and shade is unique, resulting from a spontaneous saggar firing: the vase was placed inside a small closed container along with plant materials and natural salts, and fired in a gas kiln.

The palette of reds, oranges, ochres, and blacks comes from the organic materials used: iron wires left dark, irregular marks, banana peels created pastel gray streaks, and soda salts produced delicate light oranges. Leaves from various plants added soft, smoky impressions, creating a unique and organic texture.

Finally, the vase was polished with a natural protective wax to preserve its beauty over time.

TITOLO: Decorative ceramic plate, gold kintsugi, dark glaze, hand-painted slips, wood-fired saggar raku
DESCRIZIONE: This unique piece combines traditional and contemporary ceramic techniques. The bisque was first gas-fired in a Raku kiln to create a glossy dark interior glaze. The exterior was then hand-painted with slips and sealed earth pigments before undergoing a saggar firing, leaving natural, one-of-a-kind marks and shades. Finally, modern kintsugi highlights the cracks with gold, symbolizing strength and resilience through challenges.

TITOLO: Wood-fired raku vase – primitive rustic pottery with smoke marks, hand-painted earth pigments
DESCRIZIONE:
Vase entirely handmade using the coil-building technique. It is decorated with slips and ceramic pigments and wood-fired using pit firing, enclosed in a clay shell following the saggar technique. Inside the saggar, combustible plant materials, copper wire, iron straw, and salts were added, leaving unique marks and shades on the surface of the pottery.
The interior of the vase is glazed using the Raku technique.

TITOLO: Pit-fired vase, primitive rustic pottery, smoke marks, hand painted, golden moon
DESCRIZIONE:
Handmade vase created using the coil-building technique. It is decorated with ceramic slips and pigments and wood-fired in a pit firing, enclosed in a clay shell following the saggar technique. Inside the saggar, natural combustible materials, copper wire, steel wool, and salts were used, leaving unique smoke marks and organic patterns on the ceramic surface.

The interior of the vase is glazed in an amber yellow using the Raku technique. An engraved golden moon decorates the top of the vessel.

The vase represents family, depicted in a primitive-style illustration of parents and a child holding hands, symbolizing the primordial bond between mothers, fathers, and children.
The moon evokes the intimate and ancestral connection between humanity and nature.

TITOLO: Saggar-fired red vase, copper wire and leave marks
DESCRIZIONE:
This vase features a vibrant range of reds and oranges, accented by black smoke marks, a black cross created by traces of copper wire, and delicate gray leaf imprints. It is a small vase designed as a decorative object, ideal for dried plants.
This vase was wheel-thrown and then burnished with a smooth stone, as was done in ancient times, giving the unglazed ceramic surface a natural sheen.

The patterns and colors are one of a kind, the result of a spontaneous saggar firing: small sealed containers placed inside a pit. The vibrant palette of reds, ochres, and blacks comes from organic materials—plant matter, salts, and other natural elements—arranged around the vase inside the saggar.
Copper wire left deep, irregular dark marks. A wash of iron and copper produced the reddish-orange tones and delicate pastel pinks.
Leaves from different plants were used to create soft, smoky marks, giving rise to a unique and organic texture.

To finish, the vase was polished with a natural protective wax, enhancing the depth of the colors and protecting the surface.

TITOLO: Pit-fired vase, saggar technique, smoke marks and salts
DESCRIZIONE:
This vase was wheel-thrown and then burnished with a smooth stone, as was done in ancient times, giving the unglazed ceramic surface a natural sheen.

The patterns and colors are one of a kind, the result of a spontaneous saggar firing: small sealed containers placed inside a pit. The vibrant palette of reds, ochres, and blacks comes from organic materials—plant matter, salts, and other natural elements—arranged around the vase inside the saggar.

Copper wire left dark markings with deep, irregular nuances. A wash of iron and copper produced the reddish-orange tones and the delicate pastel pinks.

Leaves from different plants were used to create soft, smoky marks, giving rise to an organic and unrepeatable texture.

To finish, the vase was polished with a natural protective wax, enhancing the depth of the colors and protecting the surface.

TITOLO: Stoneware vase, brown terra sigillata on the exterior, amber raku glaze on the interior, textured surface.
DESCRIZIONE:
This vase is made of stoneware and was thrown on the potter's wheel. A thin layer of brown terra sigillata, rich in iron oxides, has been applied to the exterior surface, following a technique used in antiquity. The interior has been glazed with an amber-colored glaze and fired with the raku technique. The thermal shock the terrasigillata undergoes during raku firing provided the exterior surface an antique, textured appearance. Finally, the vase has been protected with mineral wax.
The vase is designed for interior decoration and can be paired with dried plants. However, since it is glazed on the inside, it can also hold fresh flowers, although prolonged use in this way is not recommended.

TITOLO: White stoneware vase with organic saggar fired markings for home decor
DESCRIZIONE:
Beige stoneware vase pit-fired in saggar, inspired by japanese ceramic art. 

This wheel-thrown vase made of white stoneware, burnished with a smooth stone, and wood-fired in a pit.

It is decorated using the saggar firing technique with organic materials and salts.

This vase can be used for interior decoration and is suitable for dried flower bouquets. Since the inside is treated with a sealant, it can also be used with fresh flowers.

Not suitable for food.

TITOLO: Minimalist pit fired vase with pastel pink textures and copper red blushes
DESCRIZIONE:
Unique Saggar-Pit-Fired Vessel.
This wheel-thrown, rounded vessel is a celebration of spontaneous, natural processes in ceramic art. Initially stone-burnished, its surface has a subtle sheen.

The remarkable, unrepeatable patterns and colors are the result of a saggar firing within a bonfire pit. The vibrant palette of reds, ochres, and blacks is created by materials packed around the pot:

Copper wire left dark brown or black streaks, sometimes with greenish spots in the center, as in this pot.

Diverse plant leaves on the unglazed clay created haunting smoky gray and black carbon deposits and unique textures.

Salt was used to create unique effects on one side of the vessel, leaving behind striking gray spots and soft, pastel pink halos.

To finish, the vessel was polished with a natural protective wax, enhancing the depth of the colors and protecting the raw surface. This piece is where the flames themselves become the artists, transforming clay into a unique, painterly object.

TITOLO: Pit fired saggar vase with sculpted fox head and black moon lid
DESCRIZIONE:
Vase with Fox Figure and Crescent Moon Lid, Wood-Fired in a Pit

In the saggar technique, the flame leaves permanent marks on the ceramic surface, created by the materials placed in direct contact with it. For this piece, a combination of iron wash, copper wire, sawdust, leaves, salts, and other plant-based materials was used. These natural traces are further enhanced by the polishing of the clay, done before firing through a traditional burnishing process—repeatedly rubbing the surface with a smooth stone.
The vase features a sculpted fox head, a symbol of nature and grace.

The lid represents a crescent moon, a symbol of renewal and energy. The black color comes from wood smoke and black acrylic paint.
Entirely handcrafted and wheel-thrown, this piece is also carefully sculpted. It is made of unglazed ceramic, just like pottery was for thousands of years before the invention of glaze, and has been pit-fired with wood, resulting in unique and unrepeatable chromatic and tactile effects.

The exterior has been polished with eco-friendly protective wax.
A design and decorative object for interior spaces.

TITOLO: Saggar fired vase in antique pink with black moon lid and spontaneous fire marks
DESCRIZIONE:
Lidded vase fired in saggar using organic materials such as sugar, plant leaves, sawdust, salts, and copper wire. During the wood firing, the flame creates permanent and unpredictable marks on the ceramic surface. The clay was polished before firing by repeatedly rubbing it with a smooth natural stone. The pale pink color results from iron.

This piece is entirely handcrafted. The lid is decorated with a crescent moon, blackened by wood smoke and finished with black acrylic paint.

Traces of the materials used during firing remain visible on the surface, enhancing the vase’s uniqueness. This unglazed ceramic was wood-fired in a pit, producing one-of-a-kind effects that cannot be replicated.

Finally, the exterior has been polished with eco-friendly wax. Decorative object for interior use only.

TITOLO: Red saggar fired ceramic vase with natural leaf and copper wire markings
DESCRIZIONE:
Interior vase for dried flowers, wood-fired using the saggar technique. The flame leaves marks from leaves and other organic plant materials, salts, and copper wire.

In the saggar technique, the flame leaves indelible marks on the ceramic, which come from the materials in direct contact with the surface. For this vase, an iron wash, copper wire, sawdust, leaves, salts, and other plant materials were used. Before firing, the surface is treated with terra sigillata enriched with iron oxide to give it an intense reddish-brown color. The surface has a partially polished, aged texture, achieved through burnishing with a natural stone.

This is an artistic design and decor piece, entirely handmade on the potter's wheel. This ceramic is unglazed, as pottery was for millennia before the invention of glazes, and is wood-fired. The alchemy of these natural elements creates unique and unrepeatable chromatic and tactile effects. The exterior surface was treated with a protective mineral wax.

TITOLO: Japanese inspired pit fired stoneware vessel with black lid and saggar markings
DESCRIZIONE:
Handmade saggar pit-fired ceramic vase with black lid.

This unique vase was fired in a pit using the saggar technique, with natural materials such as leaves, copper wire, and other organic elements. During the wood firing, the flame reacts with these materials, leaving spontaneous and unrepeatable markings on the surface. The result is a dramatic, textured finish that tells the story of its creation.

Entirely handmade and wheel-thrown, the vase is crafted from unglazed clay and burnished by hand using a smooth natural stone, giving it a subtle sheen. The lid was blackened by wood smoke and finished with black acrylic paint.

Finally, the surface was polished with eco-friendly wax. This piece is a refined example of contemporary artisan ceramics with Japanese inspiration and Wabi Sabi philosophy.
Perfect as a decorative object for interior spaces.

TITOLO: Wheel thrown pink saggar fired vessel with organic leaf markings and smoke textures
DESCRIZIONE:
Small vase wood-fired in a saggar with various combustible materials such as leaves, sawdust, and berries. Traces of fern leaves and other materials are visible.

The piece is unglazed ceramic, burnished with a smooth stone. It is not suitable for food use. It is a decorative object, perfect for home decor and for holding dried flowers.
